review.title: Counterexample Guided Inductive Optimization Applied to Mobile Robots Path Planning (Extended Version)
review.abstract: We describe and evaluate a novel optimization-based off-line path planning algorithm for mobile robots based on the Counterexample-Guided Inductive Optimization (CEGIO) technique. CEGIO iteratively employs counterexamples generated from Boolean Satisfiability (SAT) and Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solvers, in order to guide the optimization process and to ensure global optimization. This paper marks the first application of CEGIO for planning mobile robot path. In particular, CEGIO has been successfully applied to obtain optimal two-dimensional paths for autonomous mobile robots using off-the-shelf SAT and SMT solvers.

sections.heading: III. CEGIO-BASED PATH PLANNING
sections.text: This section describes a novel optimisation method for solving the planning problem of autonomous mobile robots. As observed by other researchers, the main objective of a planning algorithm is to generate points that are necessary to guide the mobile robot in an environment with obstacles. As observed by other researchers, it is a challenge to find the optimal path in a region, since the number of activities and obstacles in the environment can significantly increase the complexity of the planning problem. In most cases, it requires significant processing time, especially when there are many points to visit. Therefore, there is a growing need for development techniques for optimum path planning, taking into account tractor length and system energy consumption. For the planning method proposed here, the following two steps are applied: (1) encoding the environment, movement space and static obstacles (i.e. the environment is assumed to be known and contains only static obstacles); (2) using a path search method to find the paths that consist of the respective points in the space and their orientations.

sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: A. The path-planning algorithms described in Section III are entered for a general autonomous vehicle (1) = 1, and the goal is to find points that form the path. − Two experiments were designed and performed to evaluate the application of the CEGIO-based path-planning algorithm for an autonomous vehicle, but the first experiment is performed with Setting 1, in which the autonomous vehicle is deployed in a two-dimensional space with the aim of avoiding a single obstacle, as shown in Figure 3 (a).The second experiment with Setting 2 is similar to the first, except that there are now two obstacles, as shown in Figure 3 (b).The goal in both experiments is to create a path from S to T. The precision at the points that form the path is 10cm. In Setting 1, the obstacle is centered in O (x0, y0) and its radius is r = 2.5.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have presented a novel route planning algorithm for mobile robots, where the problem of optimal route planning is solved by applying the CEGIO-F algorithm. Experimental results indicate that CEGIO is able to provide optimal routes for mobile robots. However, the cumulative execution time is still high compared to traditional optimisation-based route planning algorithms. Future studies will focus on applying the CEGIO-based algorithm to three-dimensional environments and in the context of route planning in order to achieve smooth route planning.

Model checking is an automated verification procedure to exhaustively check all (reachable) systems states [17].
1) Bounded Model Checking (BMC): BMC is an important verification technique, which is based on SAT [18] or SMT [19] solvers.
1) Bounded Model Checking (BMC): BMC is an important verification technique, which is based on SAT [18] or SMT [19] solvers.

This class of techniques is defined here as counterexample guided inductive optimization (CEGIO), which is inspired by the syntax-guided synthesis (SyGuS) to perform inductive generalization based on counterexamples provided by a verification oracle [24].

CEGIO is able to successfully optimize a wide range of functions, including non-linear and non-convex optimization problems based on SAT and SMT solvers, in which data provided by counterexamples are employed to guide the verification engine, thus reducing the optimization domain [13].

As observed by other researchers, it is a challenge to find the optimal path in a region, since the number of activities and obstacles types in the environment can substantially increase the path planning problem complexity [4].

[14] proposed three different algorithm types based on CEGIO, which are suitable for different situations: the Generalized Algorithm (CEGIO-G), the Simplified Algorithm (CEGIO-S), and the Fast Algorithm (CEGIO-F).
[14], which show considerable improvement regarding optimization times.
The verification process consists of three steps: modeling, especification, and verification [13].

[14], since the cost function is convex.

metadata.abstractText: We describe and evaluate a novel optimization-based off-line path planning algorithm for mobile robots based on the Counterexample-Guided Inductive Optimization (CEGIO) technique. CEGIO iteratively employs counterexamples generated from Boolean Satisfiability (SAT) and Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solvers, in order to guide the optimization process and to ensure global optimization. This paper marks the first application of those solvers for planning mobile robot path. In particular, CEGIO has been successfully applied to obtain optimal two-dimensional paths for autonomous mobile robots using off-the-shelf SAT and SMT solvers.
